title: Exploring Minecraft's World of Builders & Businesses

rawLines.text: [Music]
Welcome to the Navit Gaming Podcast,
where it is our mission to explore the
business and future of video games. We
bring together the industry's brightest
builders, investors, and thinkers to
keep a pulse on current events, dissect
emerging trends and games, share lessons
learned, and have a great time.
This podcast is also part of Navik's
growing ecosystem which ranges from free
and premium research to consulting and
advisory services. For more information,
visit
[Music]
www.navic.co. This episode is brought to
you by Reforged Labs. In today's crowded
market, it's harder than ever for mobile
games to get noticed. Studios spend
thousands of dollars and weeks sifting
through data to find ad creatives that
work. It's just too expensive and
timeconuming. And that's why Reforge
Labs exists. Reforge Labs uses AI to
rapidly create video ads for mobile game
studios like yours, helping you test and
find a winning creative without breaking
the bank. In 24 hours or less, Reforge
Labs delivers ads that capture attention
and elevate your game above the noise.
Make marketing easy and fast with
Reforgel Labs so you can focus on
building the game you love. To learn
more, simply visit
reforgelabs.com or check out the link in
the show notes. This episode is brought
to you by HeroicLabs, which powers some
of the world's biggest games with its
heroic game stack. Its composable
products are Nakama, the open- source
back-end game server, Hero, the game
development framework for all your live
service game features, including the
complexity of managing offline mode.
Satori, the worldclass live ops product
for maximizing monetization and
retention. And lastly, the heroic cloud
to provide massive scalability. After
nearly 10 years of operation, thousands
of studios trust Heroic Labs to help
them focus on their games and not worry
about game tech or scaling for success.
To learn more and reach out, make sure
to visit
heroiclabs.com or check out the link in
the show notes. Now, let's jump into the
episode. Welcome to the Navic Gaming
Podcast. I'm your host, David Taylor,
and today we're diving into the world of
Minecraft. Not just the game, but the
massive creator ecosystem that's grown
around it. To help us unpack it all, I'm
joined by two of the most influential
creators in the Minecraft ecosystem.
Raph is the co-founder of Spark
Universe, the Minecraft UGC studio
behind Essential Mod, a live services
platform connecting millions of
Minecraft players with over 50 million
downloads and nearly 2 million monthly
active users. Spark Universe led the
development of all official in-game
content tied to the Minecraft movie,
including a DLC add-on and live event,
and are the minds behind RealismCraft, a
first of its kind overhaul of vanilla
Minecraft. Joining him is Zed, director
of CubeCraft Games, one of the most
popular Minecraft multiplayer servers in
the world. Since launching in 2012 and
becoming a Minecraft partner in 2017,
CubeCraft has reached over 100 million
players and is known for fast-paced uh
combat miniames as well as long- form
content like Sky Block. Together, we'll
walk through their journeys as top
Minecraft creators, explore the
evolution of the Minecraft UGC
ecosystem, and dig into what it takes to
succeed as a creator on the platform
today. Welcome to the podcast, guys. Hi.
Yeah, nice to be here. So, just to kick
things off, maybe we can start with
Raph. I'd love to hear your story of how
you got here today uh as a top Minecraft
creator. I think I think my story starts
how how most people's story starts ended
up in any place in this industry, which
is I was a Minecraft player when I was a
kid at this point over 12 12 13 years
ago. Um and very early on started
creating worlds and content in Minecraft
just as a hobby. So, uh, like I I made a
server with friends, I think in in 2013
as my first real project and then kind
of branch out of that and for years and
years just made projects for the fun of
it. And then, um, when I got a little
bit older, um, I think it was around
2015 or 2016, we started having some
opportunities to work for YouTubers,
make a little bit of money, nothing big,
but when you're when you're a kid, you
you'll take it, right? and and had then
the opportunity straight out of school
to found a company with friends that
that we called Spark Universe and which
turned into a pretty major player in the
space.
Awesome. Uh and just a follow-up
question like would love to understand
sort of the journey of Spark Universe
too of like you know you you founded it
but was it all you know did you
immediately become the top creator uh or
did it take some time to get there? We
we did get pretty lucky on but we
definitely weren't weren't the top
creator from day one. We we really when
we started our goal I think was to make
a little bit of money and and see if we
can make a living. We didn't start with
with really any idea of how far we could
go. Um but we did have some
opportunities very early on that allowed
us to take it very seriously like I
think half a year after we found it
commit to it full-time with a bigger
team and started growing it. So so we
had a lot of privilege there early on to
actually say let's let's go all in on
this. Let's grow the team and let's make
this something serious.
Awesome. Zed, how about you? Love to
hear your story as well. Uh yeah, so I'm
slightly different from Raph. Uh I was a
bad Minecraft player. Uh so uh I quickly
found uh I went into the server side uh
running the Minecraft servers and SMPPS
with my friends at school. Uh and then
from there, that's how I got more into
the the dev and tech stuff. Um similar
um I did a bit of work for YouTubers and
smaller servers. Um, and then I met uh
my friend Rubik who had founded
CubeCraft in 2012. Uh, and I joined the
team uh towards the back end of 2014,
start of 2015. I think I was about 14 or
15 at the time. Um, and that's where I
kind of really sunk my teeth into uh the
tech of CubeCraft and building out the
uh the server some more. Um, and we we
were seeing some pretty big player
counts even back then uh on the Java
version of Minecraft. We used to be used
to be quite large in Europe. Um and uh
yeah, kind of escalated uncontrollably
from there and and here we are now.
Awesome. I'd love to just take a moment
to like when you say you started a
server, like what does that entail
exactly? Like what what does it mean to
start a server and uh what's sort of the
the pieces you need to pull together and
then how does a player experience that?
Yeah, I think so. One of the great
things about Minecraft is actually the
story of how CubeCraft starts and the
story of how is very similar to how the
story of how any Minecraft server
starts. You start kind of with an idea.
Um, you find plugins on Spigot forums or
Bucket forums or whatever it was back
then. Um, or or mods if you're doing
kind of a modded experience. you you put
them all together in a way that you
think works and you you put it out into
the world and people like it and come
and play it or they don't and you try
again. Um and you know we're we were
very lucky that we we got it right and
we we got players. Um but you know we
started there you know at the the the
start of CubeCraft we were downloading
plugins. We then got into writing our
own uh code for for the the server
software. Um, and now obviously we are a
much more complex technical operation.
Um, but our our origins is the same as
as every other every other Minecraft
server. And just uh just so that I can
sort of better understand or in the
audience as well like what is a plugin
and what is a mod and how do you think
about these different uh you know
product types?
Yeah. So I mean that they're pretty
similar. Plugins just within Minecraft
generally mean server side. So you'd
you'd be on a normal Minecraft client
and then you join the server and the
server's got a customized experience
with plugins. Uh mods generally refers
more to client side. So uh well we've
got a client model on the call with Raph
who who runs a who runs Essential. Um
and that's usually customizing stuff
within the the game that you have on
your computer. Um which may or may not
have a multiplayer component as well.
Got it. Got it. All right. Thanks for
that just initial. I think it's
important to level set on like all the
different things that need to come
together to create an experience for the
player. Um, before we get deeper into
that side of stuff, I just want to ask
like uh on the Minecraft movie side, did
you guys see it? What was what did you
guys think? Uh, also and then also just
curious like how did that affect your
respective audiences? Did you see a
massive spike in players? Like what's
what's been the effect of that whole
moment?
I think I think anyone that works in the
Minecraft industry will have have seen
the movie. It's pretty impossible not
to. Uh definitely had a fun time. I
think it's a it's a great moment for the
franchise and just generally bringing it
to more people's minds. The amount of
people that have started talking to me
about Minecraft now that know I work in
Minecraft but previously never had any
understanding of what it was, I think um
has has significantly increased. So,
it's definitely doing something to kind
of bring it even more into the
mainstream and and make people
understand what Minecraft is that maybe
aren't gamers themselves. So, I think
that's a really nice impact it's having.
And then from an audience perspective,
we've definitely seen it um an increased
interest and and people playing
Minecraft. I think lots of people that
used to play Minecraft maybe years and
years ago are coming back to it now out
of nostalgia. And I think that's
something we can see reflected across
all of the things we're we're working
on. I think more so even like most so
for essential where we're a platform for
players to play with together with their
friends. So that's really been powerful
for us.
Awesome. Zen, how about you? Yes. So I
mean uh I'm a big fan of School of Rock,
which is a very famous Jack Black movie.
So I I really enjoyed it. I thought it
was good fun. Um uh you know it was we
went as a team and watched it. It was, I
guess, somewhat of a surreal experience
to see this franchise that we've been
working with for for over a decade up on
a up on a big screen. Um, but uh yeah, I
mean, phenomenal moment for the brand.
Uh, we've definitely seen really
actually on our kind of legacy and
nostalgic content is where we've seen
the the resurgence as well. So, uh,
that's been on our Java network and some
of our older content where people have
played with friends years ago, uh,
either aged out or moved on to different
things and are now coming back. And, um,
yeah, I mean, I I still meet lots of
people who don't really understand what
my job is, but they're definitely more
more likely to recognize what Minecraft
is now.
Awesome. So, it sounds like the movie
sort of did a good job of of um
embodying the Minecraft legacy story IP.
Uh you guys are pretty happy with how it
was how it was portrayed. Absolutely. I
think I think um there's something that
that Minecraft keeps saying about the
movie, which is that it's not the
canonized story of Minecraft, but it's
just an adventure or a story told within
the the universe of Minecraft. And I
think that's that's a great reflection
of of what the Minecraft community is
all about. And I think they did a great
job. So very much loved it.
Awesome. Cool. All right. Well, let's
dive into the sort of the um UGC side of
things. Could you give us, you know, you
talked a little bit about your
histories, but as you see it, could you
give us a brief history on the Minecraft
creator ecosystem, how it's evolved over
time, the different platforms that
existed and that now exists today, and
how that has shaped, you know, your
respective roles in the space. I I think
um you're asking a very very complex
question there which is like a general
interesting thing about the Minecraft
ecosystem and is it's a big reason why
people struggle understanding it is
there's two different versions of
Minecraft. There's the Bedrock version
which runs on mostly used on consoles,
mobile and all of that. There's Java
edition which is the original version of
the game. Those are two pretty separate
ecosystems and then within those
ecosystems there's another layer of
separate ecosystems that exist and that
makes it incredibly difficult to talk
about what the history of it all is
where where it's coming from. Which part
specifically want like we are working on
or someone else is working on. Um well
let's let's start. So you got Minecraft
bedrock you've got Minecraft Java. Yes.
Are there any other versions that you
know existed and no longer exist or
should we just focus on those two and
then you can give us sort of like the
different segments of those uh platforms
as well? Uh so that there used to be a
pocket edition that then was retired and
replaced by bedrock. I'm not sure was
was there something that was story.
Yeah, there was also raspberry there was
the raspberry pi edition which had some
like educational uh parts of it. There's
also a whole Minecraft education edition
is a whole separate thing as well. Um
yeah, I mean I think from from my side,
you know, Minecraft is the story of UGC
before it before it was called UGC. Um
you know, even when uh in the very very
early uh Moyang days, um before
Minecraft was a household name, it was
released and people started modding it
uh or tweaking it and making it their
own. uh you know, you can trace back
some of the the the the origins of some
of the projects that are still used
today to as early back as kind of 2010,
2009 and and and even earlier. Um and I
think that's what was always special
about the Minecraft brand was that um it
had that flourishing ecosystem of you
had the content created by the studio
and then you had the content created by
the creator ecosystem uh around it. Um,
and and it's only really been in the
past four or five years that we would
use the label UGC. Um, uh, it it was
just we were just modding and, uh,
making making cool content. Awesome.
Anything to add there, Raph? Yeah, I I
think that summarized it really nicely.
And Minecraft has definitely been a UGC
ecosystem for as long as it existed. Um,
and I think I think Roblox is also very
old now, but I think I think Roblox
really had its big big moment and it its
big jump into relevance much later than
than Minecraft had its big content
ecosystem already. And um, especially
with with servers and mods in the early
days, Minecraft has always had this
massive community of people, lots of
which are doing it as a hobby, just
creating this amazing content that
people people love to play.
Got it. Now, so, so going back to the
original question though, like like how
has the platform evolved, right? Like
Minecraft Java I believe was the earlier
version. What was happening on that?
What was the creator experience like on
Minecraft Java? What were they built?
What were creators building? And then
how did that transition to Minecraft
Bedrock? And how has that changed what a
creator does on the platform?
I I think there's um there's a few
things that happened. Creating content
in Minecraft has always been scrappy. I
would say it's still scrappy today, but
in very different ways. And that's
that's maybe very difficult to explain,
but I think when we started out, um we
had to build all all of the like all of
the custom server like integrations and
technology from the ground up. Nowadays,
there's lots of community tools for
that. there's also lots of support that
Microsoft is giving and lots of lots of
tools that they are building. Um what's
what's happening nowadays is more so
pushing the boundaries of that and kind
of trying to go further than what the
technology should be allowing and trying
to find ways to do things that nobody
else has come up with and and pushing
the boundaries. So I think the the
scrappiness has shifted from originally
we had to be scrappy just to build
content at all and now we have to be
scrappy to push the boundaries of what
content we can build. Um, so that's a
very positive development. I I think
another thing that's that's really
happened is that it's become a bit it's
become easier to build a commercial
operation on top of Minecraft, which um
not everyone loves that, but I think the
reality is is that lots of creators
started as kids and then grew up and and
started um having to to make money and
earn a living. So, so nowadays I myself
I wouldn't be able to still be making
projects in Minecraft to the extent I am
now if I wasn't being paid for it if it
wasn't earning earning money for us. And
I think that that goes for thousands and
thousands of people creating content on
Minecraft every day that they can now do
it as a job because the ecosystem uh is
enabling monetization to a much greater
extent than originally where we had to
do everything ourselves and we're also
limited to some extent than what was
possible. Got it. Yeah. I I I I
unfortunately have bills to pay as well
now. Um you know, I think the big
difference with Minecraft compared to
Roblox and Fortnite is that in those
ecosystems, you the creator tools are
given and packaged and you're
constrained by the platform a lot more.
I think the culture within Minecraft has
always been well, what do you want to
build and find a way to build it. Um,
and the the level of modification and
uh, you know, Raph would call it
scrappiness, I'd call it hackiness, you
know, whatever. Um, that that's always
been inherent of the creator culture in
Minecraft. We break the game in ways
that Moyang never envisioned. Um, and
that creates brand new experiences for
players. you know, the difference in,
you know, the difference visually, um,
from a gameplay perspective, from a tech
perspective, from the the base vanilla
game, and some of the experiences both
on Java and also pushing the boundaries
in marketplace and on the Bedrock
Edition are are are so vast and and
really unlike what you see in in Roblox
or Fortnite or any other UGC platform.
Okay, you just laid out a couple of
different terms that I think the
audience may not know. I did. So, we had
So, so I think we need to define a few
things. Minecraft Bedrock, Minecraft
Java, Minecraft vanilla version. Uh I
what else? There might have been
something else, but I can't remember
what the what the fourth was. Yeah. So,
uh vanilla is how we refer to the base
game. So, that's if you download uh
Minecraft from the Microsoft Store or
wherever wherever you get it. Um and you
you play the game, the single player
version of it. Uh that's what we kind of
call the vanilla base. Um, and then when
we add stuff onto that, whether that's
through servers, whether that's through
marketplace packs, we that's generally
referred to as non vanilla content. It's
not it's not part of the default flavor
of Minecraft. Um, with Bedrock Edition
and Java Edition, it's really just a
thing of history. Um, when Minecraft was
first released, it used a programming
language called Java. That's why it's
called the uh the the the uh Java
edition. Unfortunately, it's not based
on coffee or an island. Um, and uh,
that's the one which had the biggest
modding ecosystem around it. Um, Bedrock
Edition came later. Uh, that was a
rewrite of the Minecraft engine from
scratch. Uh, so that it could run on
consoles, so PlayStation, Switch, Xbox,
and also on mobile devices, Android and
iOS. Um, and that's a to almost
effectively an entirely different title
and game engine to the Java edition of
of the game.
Got it. So Minecraft Java is PC only. Uh
Minecraft Bedrock is every other
platform plus PC as well. Yeah. Um and
then sort of segueing into the to the
next question around, you know, business
models. You know, you guys have two very
different businesses. Could you sort of
contextualize the platforms themselves
in terms of the business models and and
how you guys make money as creators?
Yeah. So I I think with with Spark we're
a bit unique as to we have actually two
separate things we're doing that are two
entirely independent business models. Um
and I'll just talk about both of them. I
think the the first one and the one we
started with is creating content for
Minecraft Bedrock Edition. Um where
there's an official Minecraft
marketplace which is powered by
Minecraft and it allows us to create
content and sell to users. And that
content ranges very wide. We can create
skins for people to wear. We can create
cosmetics for people to wear. We can
create like big expansive story DLCs
that w with hours of content. We can
create mods that just change the
Minecraft um vanilla gameplay
experience. Uh we can create texture
packs that um make the game look a bit
different and then change the textures
of the game. So there's lots of things
we can do there. Um and that's a really
big part of our team. Um, and and where
we started is just creating content that
players can buy and hopefully have a
better time playing the game with. And
then the other side of our business is
the essential mod, which we also already
briefly talked about, but that's a a mod
we make for Minecraft Java Edition. And
it's effectively a quality of life and
social platform that people can add to
their game. And we have in-game
integrated friend system, chat system,
um letting people play together um in in
their worlds with just peer-to-peer
hosting without having to buy a server
somewhere else. Um having an in-game
screenshot manager and editor and all
these kind of things. And the idea was
kind of to make Minecraft Java Edition
more accessible to casual players and
also players that may be coming from
Bedrock and now have a PC and want to
switch to the the more prevalent version
on on um on PC, which is Java. Whereas
like Zed said, Java, the Java edition is
the one that was started at this point
16 years ago. Um, and it still kind of
runs like like software from 16 years
ago in in some ways where it's just not
all that easy to use and we're trying to
to bridge that gap a little bit with
with our project. Zen, you want to take
us through the Yeah. So, so CubeCraft is
a server. Uh, we monetize on top of it
with uh ranks and cosmetics mainly. Uh,
so ranks are kind of like battle passes.
you can uh buy uh a rank for a certain
game or for for the network and that
will give you the ability to vote for
game options. Um allows you to um you
know fly in a lobby and a few other like
non uh we're not pay to win. We're quite
small on how we do our commercial model
to be fair. And then we we do cosmetics
uh which is um you know skins, pets,
whatever that might be uh within the
within the um uh game itself so that you
can customize the look and feel um of
your game play uh depending on what you
want. Um I think for for us and our
business model is is we have a pretty
pretty simple one which is uh quite a
player first centric approach. Uh, I
think our general idea is that if we
have millions of players, um, it doesn't
really matter if we're quite bad at the
conversion into the the actual dollar
amount per player because, uh, even if
you're doing it on fractions of a penny,
you're probably going to be all right at
the at the end of the month. Um, and I
think that's a big reason of why
CubeCraft has been around for, um, well,
over 10 years now is that we've never
really optimized for for revenue
extraction. It's always just been play
count. Um, and then, uh, somehow it all
adds up at the end of the month with
with the stuff that we do sell. Um, and
hopefully it continues to do so. So, so
could you give us a little more color on
like what what are the um like what are
the different game modes that you've
created? Uh, are you creating new game
modes within a single experience? Are
you creating entirely new experiences?
like how does how does the how do you
like manage your your content so that
you're continually keeping players
engaged and what is also I just curious
to get like if you could give us the
user experience of how uh a Minecraft
player engages with your content. Yeah.
Uh
so I think for for CubeCraft um you
effectively join us. Um, so on the
Bedrock editions, we're we're pre-listed
when you install the game. On the Java
edition, you type play.cupcraft.net into
where you want to join. Um, and then
you're effectively connected to our
infrastructure and and we then take
control of your client. Um, uh, and what
you see and the worlds that you're
presented with. Um, so the best way I
could explain it is we treat Minecraft
as a game engine in its own right. Um,
so on top of Minecraft and the mechanics
and the graphics that are already there,
we add new game features, uh, we're
quite well known for what I call islands
in the sky, um, game modes. So, Skywars,
Egg Wars, Bedw Wars, um Lucky Islands,
where uh you're in matches of uh
anywhere between 8 to well, some of them
are 50 50 v50 uh you know, but you're in
matches with um other players, uh
usually team- based or sometimes solo,
and you're battling through PvP um to um
uh you know, win.
Yeah. Yeah. I I think I think for us
with with our bedrock content um we
create separate experiences where where
every time we release something is its
own name, its own brand and its own type
of content. Um, something that we've
seen shift over the last um, few years
is that I think when the marketplace
ecosystem started, you had to release
new content all the time because content
stopped being relevant a few months
after that was released and it would
just go to absolute zero and it wouldn't
make you anything and you couldn't
sustain a business on top of it. Um,
that's shifting nowadays where we can
when we create something really cool
that people really want, we can keep it
relevant for a lot longer and it's
become a lot more viable for us to have
a product come out and then maintain it,
update it and and build a brand around
it, which is a really awesome
development because I think as as a
content development team, it's very
exhausting to do something new every 3
months and it's much more fun to build
something really big and then update it
and keep it relevant. So, that's really
awesome. Um, and then I think I think
the way we generally approach creating
content, um, especially on Bedrock, is
that we're not really trying to make
games in Minecraft, but we're trying to
make Minecraft games. And what we mean
by that is that we're trying to not just
use Minecraft as an engine for whatever
we come up with, but that we're trying
to leverage the features and the the
brand and the experience that is
Minecraft and just build on top of it
instead of just replacing it. Got it.
So, what's an example of something that
you and and I know that there's items
and there's experiences
like what's an example of and and if
you've done both like would love an
example of of the actual like experience
you created or the items that you
created in to help clarify that. Yeah, I
mean I can talk about realism craft
which also was was briefly mentioned in
intro. It's a project we released at
this point around about a year ago. And
it's a complete overhaul of the vanilla
Minecraft experience where we just did a
lot to change the atmosphere of the
Minecraft world and and to kind of
overhaul the visual feel, but also the
gameplay of of what Minecraft is in a
way that that we would like it to be, in
a way that we would imagine it to be.
Um, and that's really hit enough with
players, and we're actually working on a
really big update to it right now that
will um take it another step further.
So, so that's a really cool project
that's that's been going on for us for
the last year or so.
Cool. And um and so Zed, you mentioned
sort of, you know, my ears perked up
when you said bedwars cuz you see
bedwars on, you know, Fortnite and and
Roblox as ecosystems as well. Uh, I'm
curious like how do you think about like
actually not even how do you think about
I'm I'm just trying trying to understand
like the the origin of those of those
IPs or of those game game types like
where did they come from? Do you have a
perspective on like on how these um
different types of game play get
translated across different ecosystems?
Yeah, I mean so it's it's quite
interesting really. Bedw Wars is a great
example of how ideas iterate and bounce
around the Minecraft um creator
ecosystem for uh years and years really.
You can trace you trace it back probably
to um I guess survival games is probably
its origin which was kind of you know
inspired by the Hunger Games series. Uh
you then have a you that came into
Minecraft. Someone then had the idea of
putting it into the sky. Um and so that
you were spawned on these islands. Um um
